questions.question: A bobsleigh team accelerates from an initial speed of $1.5\text{ m/s}$ to a final speed of $18\text{ m/s}$ over a distance of $45\text{ m}$. Assuming constant acceleration, calculate the average acceleration of the bobsleigh.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2ad$: $(18)^2 = (1.5)^2 + 2a(45) \rightarrow 324 = 2.25 + 90a \rightarrow a = 321.75/90 \approx 3.575 \approx 3.6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A subway train travels $220\text{ m}$ while decelerating uniformly at $1.1\text{ m/s}^2$ to a final speed of $4.0\text{ m/s}$. Determine the initial speed of the train.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2ad$: $4^2 = v_i^2 + 2(-1.1)(220) \rightarrow 16 = v_i^2 - 484 \rightarrow v_i^2 = 500 \rightarrow v_i = \sqrt{500} \approx 22.36 \approx 22\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A set of keys is tossed vertically upward with an initial speed of $14\text{ m/s}$ from a window $12\text{ m}$ above the pavement. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the speed of the keys just before they hit the ground.
An astronaut on a moon where the acceleration due to gravity is $g = 1.6\text{ m/s}^2$ drops a tool from a height of $3.5\text{ m}$. Calculate the time it takes for the tool to reach the surface.
questions.explanation: Using $h = \frac{1}{2}gt^2$: $3.5 = 0.5 \times 1.6 \times t^2 = 0.8t^2 \rightarrow t^2 = 3.5/0.8 = 4.375 \rightarrow t = \sqrt{4.375} \approx 2.09 \approx 2.1\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A golfer hits a ball with an initial speed of $28\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $35^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal distance the ball travels before landing at the same elevation.
questions.explanation: Using the range formula: $R = \frac{v_i^2 \sin(2\theta)}{g} = \frac{28^2 \sin(70^{\circ})}{9.8} = \frac{784 \times 0.9397}{9.8} = \frac{736.7}{9.8} \approx 75.17 \approx 75\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A stunt plane flying horizontally at $120\text{ m/s}$ releases a flare. If the flare is in the air for $6.2\text{ s}$ before hitting the ground, calculate the altitude of the plane. Neglect air resistance.
questions.explanation: The time of fall depends only on vertical motion: $h = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = 4.9 \times (6.2)^2 = 4.9 \times 38.44 \approx 188.4 \approx 190\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A baseball is launched with an initial speed of $22\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $50^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of its velocity at its maximum height.
questions.explanation: At maximum height, the vertical component of velocity is zero, so the velocity equals the horizontal component: $v = v_x = v_i \cos\theta = 22 \cos50^{\circ} = 22 \times 0.6428 \approx 14.14 \approx 14\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A ferry travels at a speed of $4.5\text{ m/s}$ relative to the water. It aims at an angle of $25^{\circ}$ upstream to cross a river with a current of $2.5\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the ferry's velocity relative to the shore (magnitude).
questions.explanation: The upstream component is $4.5\sin25^{\circ} = 4.5 \times 0.4226 = 1.902\text{ m/s}$. The net velocity perpendicular to the shore is $v_y = 4.5\cos25^{\circ} = 4.5 \times 0.9063 = 4.078\text{ m/s}$. The velocity parallel to the shore is $v_x = 2.5 - 1.902 = 0.598\text{ m/s}$. The magnitude is $v = \sqrt{0.598^2 + 4.078^2} = \sqrt{0.358 + 16.63} = \sqrt{16.988} \approx 4.12 \approx 4.1\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A travels North at $105\text{ km/h}$ and Car B travels North at $82\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of Car A relative to Car B.
questions.explanation: Relative velocity: $\vec{v}_{A/B} = \vec{v}_A - \vec{v}_B = 105 - 82 = 23\text{ km/h North}$.

questions.question: A crate of mass $32\text{ kg}$ is pushed across a horizontal surface with a horizontal force of $150\text{ N}$. If the crate accelerates at $1.8\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and the surface.
questions.explanation: Net force: $F_{net} = ma = 32 \times 1.8 = 57.6\text{ N}$. Friction force: $f_k = F_{app} - F_{net} = 150 - 57.6 = 92.4\text{ N}$. Coefficient of kinetic friction: $\mu_k = f_k/(mg) = 92.4/(32 \times 9.8) = 92.4/313.6 \approx 0.295 \approx 0.29$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1600\text{ kg}$ traveling at $32\text{ m/s}$ comes to a stop in a distance of $65\text{ m}$. Assuming constant deceleration, calculate the magnitude of the net braking force acting on the car.
questions.explanation: First find acceleration using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$: $0 = (32)^2 + 2a(65) \rightarrow a = -1024/130 = -7.877\text{ m/s}^2$. Then force magnitude: $F = m|a| = 1600 \times 7.877 \approx 12,603 \approx 1.3 \times 10^4\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $4.0\text{ kg}$ block is pulled by a rope at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ above the horizontal with a tension of $20\text{ N}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the surface is $\mu_k = 0.15$, calculate the acceleration of the block.
questions.explanation: Horizontal component: $F_x = T\cos30^{\circ} = 20 \times 0.8660 = 17.32\text{ N}$. Vertical component: $F_y = T\sin30^{\circ} = 20 \times 0.5 = 10\text{ N}$ upward. Normal force: $N = mg - F_y = 4.0 \times 9.8 - 10 = 39.2 - 10 = 29.2\text{ N}$. Friction force: $f_k = \mu_k N = 0.15 \times 29.2 = 4.38\text{ N}$. Net force: $F_{net} = F_x - f_k = 17.32 - 4.38 = 12.94\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_{net}/m = 12.94/4.0 \approx 3.235 \approx 3.2\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $5.5\text{ kg}$ block is placed on an incline that makes an angle of $42^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. If the coefficient of static friction between the block and the incline is $0.65$, determine whether the block will slide down the incline.
options: No, it will remain at rest
questions.explanation: Component of weight down the incline: $F_\parallel = mg\sin\theta = 5.5 \times 9.8 \times \sin42^{\circ} = 53.9 \times 0.6691 = 36.06\text{ N}$. Normal force: $N = mg\cos\theta = 53.9 \times \cos42^{\circ} = 53.9 \times 0.7431 = 40.05\text{ N}$. Maximum static friction: $f_{s,max} = \mu_s N = 0.65 \times 40.05 = 26.03\text{ N}$. Since $F_\parallel > f_{s,max}$, the block will slide.

questions.question: A $12\text{ kg}$ crate is pushed up a $20^{\circ}$ frictionless incline at a constant speed. Calculate the magnitude of the pushing force required, assuming the force is applied parallel to the incline.
questions.explanation: On a frictionless incline, constant speed requires the pushing force to balance the component of weight down the incline: $F_{push} = mg\sin\theta = 12 \times 9.8 \times \sin20^{\circ} = 117.6 \times 0.3420 \approx 40.22 \approx 40\text{ N}$.

questions.question: In an Atwood machine, masses $m_1 = 3.2\text{ kg}$ and $m_2 = 5.8\text{ kg}$ are connected by a light string over a frictionless, massless pulley. Calculate the tension in the string once the masses are released from rest.
questions.explanation: Acceleration: $a = g\frac{m_2 - m_1}{m_1 + m_2} = 9.8 \times \frac{5.8 - 3.2}{9.0} = 9.8 \times \frac{2.6}{9.0} = 9.8 \times 0.2889 = 2.83\text{ m/s}^2$. Tension (using the smaller mass): $T = m_1(g + a) = 3.2(9.8 + 2.83) = 3.2 \times 12.63 \approx 40.42 \approx 40\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $14\text{ kg}$ mass on a horizontal frictionless table is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $7.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Starting from rest, calculate the time it takes for the system to move a distance of $2.5\text{ m}$.
questions.explanation: Acceleration: $a = \frac{m_2g}{m_1 + m_2} = \frac{7.0 \times 9.8}{21} = 68.6/21 = 3.267\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $s = \frac{1}{2}at^2$: $t = \sqrt{2s/a} = \sqrt{5/3.267} = \sqrt{1.53} \approx 1.237 \approx 1.2\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A $25\text{ kg}$ heavy bag is supported by two chains, each making an angle of $45^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Calculate the tension in each chain.
questions.explanation: Vertical equilibrium: $2T\cos45^{\circ} = mg = 25 \times 9.8 = 245\text{ N}$. Since $\cos45^{\circ} = 0.7071$, $2T(0.7071) = 1.4142T = 245 \rightarrow T = 245/1.4142 \approx 173.2 \approx 170\text{ N}$ (closest to 170).

questions.question: A $75\text{ kg}$ person is in an elevator that is accelerating downward at $2.2\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate their apparent weight (the normal force exerted by the scale).
questions.explanation: When accelerating downward, the apparent weight is $N = m(g - a) = 75(9.8 - 2.2) = 75 \times 7.6 = 570\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A computer hard drive platter has a radius of $4.8\text{ cm}$ and rotates at $7200\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Calculate the centripetal acceleration of a point on the outer edge.
questions.explanation: Radius: $r = 0.048\text{ m}$. Angular velocity: $\omega = 7200 \times \frac{2\pi}{60} = 7200 \times 0.10472 = 754.0\text{ rad/s}$. Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = r\omega^2 = 0.048 \times (754.0)^2 = 0.048 \times 568,516 \approx 27,289 \approx 2.7 \times 10^4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: An object moves in a circle of radius $2.5\text{ m}$ with a period of $1.8\text{ s}$. Calculate its tangential speed.
questions.explanation: Tangential speed: $v = \frac{2\pi r}{T} = \frac{2\pi \times 2.5}{1.8} = \frac{15.708}{1.8} \approx 8.727 \approx 8.7\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.45\text{ kg}$ mass is whirled in a vertical circle of radius $0.90\text{ m}$. If the speed at the bottom of the circle is $5.5\text{ m/s}$, calculate the tension in the string at that point.

A car of mass $1200\text{ kg}$ goes over the crest of a circular hill with a radius of $40\text{ m}$. If the normal force exerted by the road on the car is half the car's weight, calculate the car's speed at the crest.
questions.explanation: At the crest, $mg - N = \frac{mv^2}{R}$. With $N = 0.5mg$, we have $mg - 0.5mg = 0.5mg = \frac{mv^2}{R} \rightarrow v = \sqrt{0.5gR} = \sqrt{0.5 \times 9.8 \times 40} = \sqrt{196} = 14\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1400\text{ kg}$ rounds a flat, unbanked curve with a radius of $70\text{ m}$ at a constant speed of $22\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the minimum coefficient of static friction required to prevent skidding.
questions.explanation: The friction force provides the centripetal force: $\mu_s mg = \frac{mv^2}{R} \rightarrow \mu_s = \frac{v^2}{Rg} = \frac{22^2}{70 \times 9.8} = \frac{484}{686} \approx 0.705 \approx 0.71$.

questions.question: A $0.30\text{ kg}$ ball is swung in a horizontal circle by a string of length $1.5\text{ m}$. If the tension in the string is $18\text{ N}$, calculate the frequency of rotation.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, $T = m\omega^2 r = m(2\pi f)^2 r = m4\pi^2 r f^2$. Solving for $f$: $f = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{T}{mr}} = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{18}{0.30 \times 1.5}} = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{18}{0.45}} = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{40} = \frac{6.324}{6.283} \approx 1.007 \approx 1.0\text{ Hz}$. Closest to 1.2 Hz among the options.

questions.question: Calculate the gravitational force between two $1500\text{ kg}$ satellites that are separated by $35\text{ m}$. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
If a planet has three times the radius of Earth and nine times the mass of Earth, how does the acceleration due to gravity on its surface compare to Earth's?
questions.explanation: $g_p = G\frac{9M_E}{(3R_E)^2} = G\frac{9M_E}{9R_E^2} = G\frac{M_E}{R_E^2} = g_E$. Therefore it is the same as Earth's.

questions.question: A $45\text{ kg}$ crate is pushed a distance of $15\text{ m}$ across a floor at a constant speed. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and the floor is $0.38$, calculate the work done by the friction force.
questions.explanation: Friction force: $f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.38 \times 45 \times 9.8 = 0.38 \times 441 = 167.58\text{ N}$. Work done by friction: $W_f = -f_k d = -167.58 \times 15 = -2513.7 \approx -2.51 \times 10^3 \approx -2.5 \times 10^3\text{ J}$.

questions.question: Calculate the work required to bring a $1300\text{ kg}$ car traveling at $26\text{ m/s}$ to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Work equals the change in kinetic energy: $W = \Delta KE = 0 - \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = -0.5 \times 1300 \times (26)^2 = -650 \times 676 = -439,400 \approx -4.39 \times 10^5 \approx -4.4 \times 10^5\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $0.20\text{ kg}$ arrow is fired with $160\text{ J}$ of kinetic energy. Calculate its speed.
questions.explanation: $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \rightarrow 160 = 0.5 \times 0.20 \times v^2 = 0.1v^2 \rightarrow v^2 = 1600 \rightarrow v = 40\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.40\text{ kg}$ ball is thrown from the top of a $22\text{ m}$ high cliff with an initial speed of $15\text{ m/s}$. If it hits the ground below with a speed of $19\text{ m/s}$, calculate the work done by air resistance during the fall.
questions.explanation: Initial total energy: $E_i = mgh + \frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 = 0.40 \times 9.8 \times 22 + 0.5 \times 0.40 \times 15^2 = 86.24 + 45 = 131.24\text{ J}$. Final kinetic energy: $E_f = \frac{1}{2}mv_f^2 = 0.5 \times 0.40 \times 19^2 = 0.2 \times 361 = 72.2\text{ J}$. Work done by air resistance: $W_{air} = E_f - E_i = 72.2 - 131.24 = -59.04 \approx -59\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $2.0\text{ kg}$ mass is attached to a vertical spring with spring constant $k = 500\text{ N/m}$. If the mass is released from the unstretched position, calculate the maximum distance it falls before coming to rest momentarily.
questions.explanation: By conservation of energy, when the mass falls a distance $x$, the gravitational potential energy lost equals the spring potential energy gained: $mgx = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$. Solving for $x$: $x = \frac{2mg}{k} = \frac{2 \times 2.0 \times 9.8}{500} = \frac{39.2}{500} = 0.0784 \approx 0.078\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A $2.2\text{ kW}$ electric motor is used to lift a $400\text{ kg}$ crate vertically at a constant speed. Calculate the time required to lift the crate a distance of $10\text{ m}$.
questions.explanation: Work required: $W = mgh = 400 \times 9.8 \times 10 = 400 \times 98 = 39,200\text{ J}$. Time: $t = W/P = 39,200/2200 = 17.82 \approx 18\text{ s}$.

questions.question: An engine provides $55\text{ HP}$ ($1\text{ HP} = 746\text{ W}$) to keep a vehicle moving at a constant speed of $28\text{ m/s}$ on a level road. Calculate the total resistive force opposing the motion.
questions.explanation: Power in watts: $P = 55 \times 746 = 41,030\text{ W}$. At constant speed, $P = Fv$, so $F = P/v = 41,030/28 \approx 1,465 \approx 1.5 \times 10^3\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the change in elastic potential energy stored in a spring with spring constant $k = 320\text{ N/m}$ when it is compressed from $0.10\text{ m}$ to $0.25\text{ m}$.
A $4.5\text{ kg}$ mass is dropped from a height of $0.50\text{ m}$ onto a vertical spring, compressing it by $0.14\text{ m}$. Calculate the spring constant.
questions.explanation: By conservation of energy: $mg(h+x) = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$. Substituting: $4.5 \times 9.8(0.50 + 0.14) = 0.5k(0.14)^2 \rightarrow 44.1 \times 0.64 = 0.5k \times 0.0196 \rightarrow 28.224 = 0.0098k \rightarrow k = 28.224/0.0098 \approx 2,880 \approx 2.9 \times 10^3\text{ N/m}$.

questions.question: A $1800\text{ kg}$ car moving West at $14\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on with a $2200\text{ kg}$ truck moving East at $8.0\text{ m/s}$. If they lock together after the collision, calculate the final velocity of the combined wreck.
questions.explanation: Take West as positive. Initial momentum: $p_i = 1800 \times 14 + 2200 \times (-8.0) = 25,200 - 17,600 = 7,600\text{ kg·m/s}$ (West). Total mass: $4000\text{ kg}$. Final velocity: $v_f = p_i/4000 = 7,600/4000 = 1.9\text{ m/s West}$.

questions.question: A $1.5\text{ kg}$ ball moving at $4.0\text{ m/s}$ hits a stationary $4.5\text{ kg}$ ball in a perfectly elastic collision. Calculate the final velocity of the $4.5\text{ kg}$ ball.
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision where the target is initially at rest, $v_{2f} = \frac{2m_1}{m_1+m_2}v_{1i} = \frac{2 \times 1.5}{6.0} \times 4.0 = \frac{3}{6} \times 4 = 0.5 \times 4 = 2.0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $5.0\text{ kg}$ object initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece of mass $1.8\text{ kg}$ moves South at $24\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the velocity of the second piece.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $0 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2$. Taking South as negative: $0 = 1.8(-24) + (5.0 - 1.8)v_2 = -43.2 + 3.2v_2 \rightarrow 3.2v_2 = 43.2 \rightarrow v_2 = 43.2/3.2 = 13.5 \approx 14\text{ m/s North}$.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $12\Omega$, $18\Omega$, and $30\Omega$ are connected in series to a $15\text{ V}$ battery. Calculate the power dissipated by the $30\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = 12 + 18 + 30 = 60\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_{total} = 15/60 = 0.25\text{ A}$. Power in $30\Omega$ resistor: $P = I^2R = (0.25)^2 \times 30 = 0.0625 \times 30 = 1.875 \approx 1.9\text{ W}$.

questions.question: Two resistors are connected in series. The total resistance is $240\Omega$. If the voltage across the first resistor is $4.0\text{ V}$ and across the second is $12\text{ V}$, calculate the resistance of each resistor.
Calculate the equivalent resistance of a $25\Omega$, a $50\Omega$, and a $100\Omega$ resistor connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{25} + \frac{1}{50} + \frac{1}{100} = \frac{4}{100} + \frac{2}{100} + \frac{1}{100} = \frac{7}{100}$. Therefore $R = 100/7 \approx 14.29 \approx 14\Omega$.

questions.question: A $12\text{ V}$ source is connected to two resistors in parallel. If the total current drawn from the source is $4.0\text{ A}$ and one of the resistors is $6\Omega$, find the value of the other resistor.
questions.explanation: Equivalent resistance: $R_{total} = V/I = 12/4.0 = 3\Omega$. For two resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{3} = \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{R_2} \rightarrow \frac{1}{R_2} = \frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{6} = \frac{2}{6} - \frac{1}{6} = \frac{1}{6} \rightarrow R_2 = 6\Omega$.

questions.question: A $40\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination of a $60\Omega$ and a $120\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the total equivalent resistance.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination gives $R_p = \frac{60 \times 120}{60 + 120} = \frac{7200}{180} = 40\Omega$. Adding the series $40\Omega$ resistor: $R_{total} = 40 + 40 = 80\Omega$.

questions.question: Find the current through a $15\Omega$ resistor that is connected in parallel with a $30\Omega$ resistor, given this parallel pair is connected in series with a $10\Omega$ resistor and a $24\text{ V}$ source.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination gives $R_p = \frac{15 \times 30}{15 + 30} = \frac{450}{45} = 10\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 10 + 10 = 20\Omega$. Total current: $I_{total} = 24/20 = 1.2\text{ A}$. Voltage across the parallel pair: $V_p = I_{total} \times R_p = 1.2 \times 10 = 12\text{ V}$. Current through the $15\Omega$ resistor: $I_{15} = V_p/15 = 12/15 = 0.80\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A string is $2.2\text{ m}$ long and has a total mass of $45\text{ g}$. If it is under a tension of $180\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of a wave on this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.045/2.2 = 0.02045\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{180/0.02045} = \sqrt{8800} \approx 93.81 \approx 94\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A wave has a frequency of $35\text{ Hz}$. If the distance between a crest and the next trough is $0.45\text{ m}$, calculate the speed of the wave.
questions.explanation: The distance from a crest to the next trough is half a wavelength, so $\lambda/2 = 0.45\text{ m} \rightarrow \lambda = 0.90\text{ m}$. Wave speed: $v = f\lambda = 35 \times 0.90 = 31.5 \approx 32\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A police siren emits a sound with frequency $750\text{ Hz}$. A stationary observer hears the siren at $810\text{ Hz}$. Calculate the speed of the police car. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: The observed frequency is higher than the emitted frequency, so the source is approaching. Using $f' = f\frac{v}{v - v_s}$: $810 = 750 \times \frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow \frac{810}{750} = \frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow 1.08 = \frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow 340 - v_s = 340/1.08 = 314.81 \rightarrow v_s = 340 - 314.81 = 25.19 \approx 25\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Two speakers emit sound in phase. Destructive interference occurs at a point where the path difference from the speakers is $1.15\text{ m}$. Calculate the frequency of the sound, assuming the longest possible wavelength. The speed of sound is $344\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For destructive interference with in-phase sources, the condition is $\Delta x = (n + \frac{1}{2})\lambda$. For the longest wavelength, take $n = 0$, giving $1.15 = \lambda/2 \rightarrow \lambda = 2.30\text{ m}$. Then $f = v/\lambda = 344/2.30 \approx 149.6 \approx 1.5 \times 10^2\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Calculate the fundamental frequency of a $55\text{ cm}$ long organ pipe that is open at both ends. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For an open pipe, the fundamental wavelength is $\lambda = 2L = 2 \times 0.55 = 1.10\text{ m}$. The fundamental frequency is $f = v/\lambda = 340/1.10 \approx 309.1 \approx 310\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves with frequencies of $340\text{ Hz}$ and $343\text{ Hz}$ interfere. Calculate the time interval between successive loud pulses (beats).
questions.explanation: Beat frequency: $f_{beat} = |343 - 340| = 3\text{ Hz}$. The time between beats (beat period) is $T_{beat} = 1/f_{beat} = 1/3 \approx 0.333 \approx 0.33\text{ s}$.
